posts.name: JAMES
posts.cooked: What are some of the most achievable robots out there this season that teams looking to up their game should try and emulate?
The first team that comes to mind is 3100. A relatively simple robot excelled in one area of the game, while allowing for improvements and iterations as the season developed.
9496 offers an easy-to-use, simple design that effectively satisfies a ground intake requirement.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: I think 254’s robot was pretty basic and simple, serving as a good introductory model. However, our team built upon 4481’s first robot, finding its simplistic design effective despite its simplicity.

posts.name: Jacob Williams
posts.cooked: 1778 Chill Out! Love the way they did the ground intake!

posts.name: waialua3:59
posts.cooked: The first team that comes to mind is 3100. A straightforward robot that excelled in one key area of the game, providing a foundation for further development and refinement as the season evolved. These guys had the best algae intake off the reef, lollipop, or ground that I observed in our division. Additionally, they were a standout L1 bot, which is why we selected them for our alliance on Curie.

posts.name: Itay Kaufman
posts.cooked: I hope to achieve 1678. Without a lead team and unresolved goals, I believe SubLime can enhance our capabilities across various areas. However, some team members anticipate building either 2910 or 2630, though I don’t think these plans are feasible.

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked: Low robots that climb among the top three scored highly in L1 competitions: 4087 and 9092. Additionally, the net algae robots that climb achieved a score of 8825. Regrettably, none of these three robots advanced to the championships because L1 and algae strategies alone weren’t sustainable, and their success ensured they wouldn’t drop to becoming a second-choice alliance. However, I believe all three could have had a chance at the championships due to the lack of proficiency in these tasks among existing robots.

posts.name: Garrison
posts.cooked: I'm self-nominating our 3128 robot built this year. We intentionally selected an architecture designed for easy climbing, minimizing both stacked and total degrees of freedom. Our robot performed exceptionally well, qualifying for regionals through its robust performance under the impressive regional points system and excelling at higher levels. We utilize only 7 motors outside the drive train, with a maximum stacked degrees of freedom ranging between 1.5 to 2, depending on counting methods.

posts.name: Vincent Banks
posts.cooked: I always think 2056 makes simple but powerful robots.

Sometimes upping your game means doing less; many teams try to do everything and end up not really perfected any of them. 9245 is one of my favorites of the season. They built a pretty effective and simple robot that filled its role perfectly. No L4, no barge, just a single-stage elevator and a funnel to score L2/3 faster than most anyone. In terms of "achievable" robots, it's hard to beat how simple and effective their design was.

link_counts.title: Laker Dreadnoughts - Team 9245 - The Blue Alliance

posts.name: Karthik Kanagasabapathy (he/him)
posts.cooked: Easy answer for me. Team 5409 - Chargers out of Oakville, Ontario. Averaged 22 pieces of coral per match at Provincials, including 3.4 pieces in auto. No ground coral intake, no algae scoring, no deep climb, yet still finished the year ranked 24th in the world in EPA. This robot was so much simpler than most robots in the world, and statistically better than 99.3% of all robots. There are many lessons to be learned from them.

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: 3863 was awesome at week 1/2 comps with a very simple l1-3 hopper bot. I saw that they added a ground intake for Champs.

posts.name: Brendan Conover
posts.cooked: Going to nominate ourselves for this one. Bit of a unique case but entirely achievable for most. A one-stage elevator, an "arm," and then a bargue style climb. Could do level 1, 2, 3, and then ascend into the barges alongside a deep climb. Adding some simple toro sticks would allow us to also perform ground algae climbs.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: The mention was appreciated. As much as we would have liked to play at CMP, getting picked seemed like a long shot unless we had added more features. The opportunity cost of losing our utility player, Robot 3rd, wasn't worth ~15 solo L1s. The scorch opportunity though...

posts.name: Reis Simpson
posts.cooked: Gotta be 1902. This bot cooks. I think if teams can explore a way to get this robot to L4 they are in business. This seems like one of the most approachable ways to do a ground coral intake.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked: 4451’s offshoot team 4864 was the kitbot, perfected. They started the season with a kitbot on brushless that had a PhotonVision-based system and a pretty slick servo-based gap filler ramp for the scoring end. Alliance 4 captain and round 3 the first time out? Not bad. By state, they’d added a deep climber using a similarly trick trap door and an Everybot climber. They were the most refined kitbot in the state to the eye test, and Statbotics backs that up (EPA of 31.9; next kitbot down was 9571 at 24.8). If you’re a Kitbot team that wants to explore the next level without completely starting over, you could do far worse than them. More pictures from their Facebook page: FRC Team 4451.

link_counts.title: Innovation Station - Team 4864 - The Blue Alliance

posts.name: James Temple
posts.cooked: I see 9496 is already mentioned above. I’d place 6324 alongside it. This simple and elegant robot is designed to maximize its capabilities mechanically, ignoring some parts that 95% of teams shouldn’t bother with, resulting in better performance.

links.title: Laker Dreadnoughts - Team 9245 - The Blue Alliance
Innovation Station - Team 4864 - The Blue Alliance
